awd_titl_txt: Altering the Course of Quantum Dynamics Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Herschel A. Rabitz of Princeton University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program to develop new theoretical concepts for quantum control.  The control of quantum phenomena entails interceding in the normal evolution of dynamical events through the introduction of external fields. Quite surprisingly, finding optimal fields for this purpose is proving to be easier than anticipated both in simulations and in the laboratory.  At Princeton, an effort has been underway to fundamentally understand the origins of this behavior.  In particular, at the most basic level, the structure of the control landscape needs to be understood, where a control landscape is the physical observable as a function of the controls.  A family of theoretical and computational analysis tools will be used to analyze these landscapes with the aim of ultimately providing insights into identifying the basic rules for controlling quantum phenomena. Part of this effort will include revealing the mechanisms by which control is achieved and the role of general Hamiltonian structure in facilitating control.  The outcome of this research is expected to be a deeper understanding of controlled quantum phenomena along with specific guidance towards promising experimental directions for the field.  A new text titled, Quantum Control Engineering, Taylor and Francis, will be co-authored by the PI and Professor R. Chakrabarti, Purdue University.

The control of dynamical events at the atomic and molecular scale is at the heart of many areas of science.  Building on the foundations of quantum mechanics and the introduction of the laser in the 1960's, an outstanding objective has been to achieve control at Angstrom length scales and ultrafast time scales. This field is motivated by the desire to manipulate and understand the fundamental dynamical processes as well as the prospects for a variety of applications.  Addressing these goals reached a milestone through the introduction of engineering control concepts within quantum mechanics and the development of ultrafast laser pulse shaping tools. Hosts of emerging experiments demonstrate many of the basic principles and promise for the field.  This research concerns the advanced development of theoretical concepts, tools and algorithms to fundamentally explore the control of quantum phenomena.  These advances aim to provide the means to better exploit the laboratory control capabilities and extract the information generated from the experiments.

por.por_cntn:
The heart of chemistry concerns the manipulation of processes at the atomic and molecular scale, including chemical reactions and the formation of materials with novel practical properties.  Such manipulation involves the movement of atoms, which naturally occurs at very small length scales and ultrafast time scales corresponding to natural atomic motion. Since the advent of the laser in the 1960’s, a wide-ranging dream in many areas of science has been to exploit these novel light sources to form “photonic reagents” in analogy with traditional chemical reagents. After many years of arduous work in laboratories around the world, success with photonic reagents for manipulating atomic and molecular scale events is now possible with growing numbers of demonstrations. The present research is concerned with pushing the frontiers of this capability, as well as considering the fundamental question of what makes light a successful tool for this purpose. Addressing the latter question is both fundamental as well as providing a basis for projecting the future prospects of the laser control field at the atomic and molecular scale. In this regard, the research involved a variety of interrelated and parallel activities but collectively focused on this key central question of why laser control is proving to be increasingly successful. The research was able to unveil major contributing factors towards answering this question, resulting in a key theorem resting on mathematical rigor but also of high practical value. In essence, the very positive conclusion from this work is that, if the chemical control objective is well posed such that the target goal is reachable and adequate laser resources are available, then the deployment of systematic automated laser control experiments should successfully find at least one photonic reagent meeting the desired goal. This sweeping result was tested successfully in large numbers of simulations as well as experimentally for the control of chemical reactions and the manipulation of atoms in nuclear magnetic resonance experiments. The overall outcome of the research provides a solid foundation to build upon, including for the design of advanced experiments for the creation of novel materials and molecules relevant in chemistry, physics, and biology. The research also has implications for control in the sciences beyond the use of lasers in quantum control of atoms and molecules. In particular, in a collaboration with a major pharmaceutical company, we were able to apply like control concepts to guide the discovery of high value complex formulations to enable utilizing the active pharmaceutical agent.
